Key Arguments: The bill is seen as an attack on freedom of speech.
It grants excessive powers to ACMA, allowing it to censor digital media platforms and regulate user content.
The bill is perceived as a government attempt to control public opinion and enforce a political narrative.
It threatens the ability of individuals to form and express their own opinions.
The bill could disproportionately affect smaller digital media companies and religious platforms.
The legislation is being rushed without proper consideration.
Historical conventions and rights, such as those implied in the Australian Constitution and Universal Human Rights, are being overlooked.
Notable Quotes: This Bill is suggesting a formation of a ‘Ministry of Truth’.
The Misinformation and Disinformation 2023 Bill, if passed will diminish Australian Citizens ‘freedom of speech’ and freedom of expression.
Australians need to be able to express and exercise their Universal Human Rights which Australia helped to draft in 1948.
